section_1_sacred_text.original_script: Ἀνὴρ δέ ⸀τις ἐν Καισαρείᾳ ὀνόματι Κορνήλιος, ἑκατοντάρχης ἐκ σπείρης τῆς καλουμένης Ἰταλικῆς,
section_1_sacred_text.faithful_direct_translation: Now a certain man in Caesarea, Cornelius by name, a centurion from the cohort being called the Italian,
section_1_sacred_text.standalone_english_translation: There was a man in Caesarea named Cornelius, a centurion of what was known as the Italian Cohort.
section_1_sacred_text.amplified_narrative_translation: Now at that time, there was a particular man of significant standing living in the city of Caesarea, whose name was Cornelius. He held the military rank of a centurion, a commander of about one hundred soldiers, belonging to the specific regiment that was officially designated as the Italian Cohort.

literal_primary_filter: The narrative of Acts pivots to a new scene, introducing a specific individual.
This person is a man named Cornelius.
He is a Gentile, not a Jew by birth.
His residence is the city of Caesarea.
His profession is that of a Roman centurion.
His military unit is identified as the Italian Cohort.
prophetic_typology_and_intertextuality: The introduction of Cornelius marks the divinely initiated fulfillment of God's ancient promise to Abraham.
The 'Type' is God's covenantal declaration that through Abraham's seed, 'all the families of the earth shall be blessed' (Genesis 12:3).
Cornelius, a Gentile, represents one of these 'families of the earth' now being brought into the covenant blessing.
This event is the 'Antitype' or apostolic realization of prophetic promises that the Gentiles would come to God's light.
Isaiah prophesied that the Messiah would be 'a light for the Gentiles' (Isaiah 42:6, Isaiah 49:6).
Joel prophesied that God would pour out His Spirit upon 'all flesh' (Joel 2:28), a promise Peter cited at Pentecost (Acts 2:17) but whose full scope is only now being revealed.
Cornelius's conversion serves as the precedent-setting case study that the Apostles would later debate and confirm at the Jerusalem Council (Acts 15:7-11).
It makes tangible the 'mystery' later explained by Paul, that Gentiles are 'fellow heirs, members of the same body, and partakers of the promise in Christ Jesus through the gospel' (Ephesians 3:6).

Thus, Cornelius is not just an individual convert; he is the beachhead for the intentional, Spirit-led mission to the entire Gentile world, fulfilling the Great Commission's mandate to 'all nations' (Matthew 28:19).
linguistic_mechanics_and_names: The text begins with [Ἀνὴρ δέ τις] (Anēr de tis, "Now a certain man").
The use of [Ἀνὴρ] (Anēr) rather than the generic [ἄνθρωπος] (anthropos) often implies a man of notable character or standing.
His name, [Κορνήλιος] (Kornēlios), is the Latin name *Cornelius*, a prominent Roman clan name, suggesting he was either a Roman citizen by birth or a freedman of the Cornelia gens.
The name is etymologically linked to the Latin *cornu*, meaning "horn," a biblical symbol of strength and power (1 Samuel 2:10; Luke 1:69).
He resides [ἐν Καισαρείᾳ] (en Kaisareia, "in Caesarea"). The city's name means "Pertaining to Caesar," highlighting its Roman identity.
His rank is [ἑκατοντάρχης] (hekatontarchēs, "centurion"), a compound of [ἑκατόν] (hekaton, "one hundred") and [ἄρχω] (archō, "to rule").
Centurions were the professional backbone of the Roman army, respected for discipline and leadership, and are consistently portrayed positively in the Gospels (Matthew 8:5-13; Luke 23:47).
He is [ἐκ σπείρης] (ek speirēs, "of the cohort"). [Σπεῖρα] is the Greek term for the Latin *cohors*, a military unit of roughly 600 men.
The cohort is specified as [τῆς καλουμένης Ἰταλικῆς] (tēs kaloumenēs Italikēs, "the one called Italian").

This designated the *Cohors II Italica Civium Romanorum*, an auxiliary unit composed of volunteer Roman citizens from Italy, which gave it a more prestigious status than typical provincial auxiliaries.
literary_devices: Luke, the author of Acts, uses Cornelius as a narrative lynchpin.
The detailed introduction of this one Gentile man serves as a literary device to personify the monumental theological shift of the Gospel officially crossing ethnic boundaries.
The structure is a careful diptych, pairing the vision of Cornelius with the parallel vision of Peter, demonstrating God working on both sides of the cultural divide to bring about His will.
numerical_and_gematria_significance: This specific verse does not contain numbers with overt symbolic weight.
However, the rank of 'centurion' ('ruler of 100') is significant in its military context, denoting a man of authority and responsibility within the most powerful empire of the age.
historical_context_and_chronology: The event can be dated with high probability to A.D. 40-41.
This places it during the reign of Roman Emperor Caligula (A.D. 37-41) and after the period of peace for the church described in Acts 9:31.
Caesarea Maritima was the administrative capital of the Roman province of Iudaea, established by Herod the Great around 22 B.C.
It was the primary residence of the Roman governor (procurator/prefect) and the main garrison for Roman troops in the region.
The city was a hub of Greco-Roman culture, commerce, and political power, standing in stark contrast to the religious and cultural center of Jerusalem.
The presence of an elite Italian cohort underscores the strategic importance of Caesarea to Roman rule.
socio_political_matrix: As a centurion, Cornelius was a direct agent of Roman imperial power, the occupying force in Judea.
This created a deep social and religious chasm between him and the Jewish people, for whom contact with a Gentile, especially a soldier, was a source of ritual defilement (John 18:28; Acts 10:28).

Cornelius, however, is presented as a 'God-fearer' (Acts 10:2), a technical term for a class of Gentiles who adopted the monotheism and ethical framework of Judaism without becoming full proselytes through circumcision.
This group represented a spiritually prepared 'bridge' community for the Gospel to cross from its Jewish origins to the wider Gentile world.
geospatial_data_and_physical_geography: The city was a major man-made port on the Mediterranean coast, roughly 65 miles (105 km) northwest of Jerusalem.
Its strategic coastal location made it the primary point of entry and exit for Roman officials and maritime trade for the province.
The geography itself—a Roman port city—symbolizes the launching point for the Gospel's journey across the Mediterranean to the rest of the Roman Empire.
archaeological_confirmation: Extensive excavations at Caesarea Maritima have unearthed Herod's palace, a theater, a hippodrome, and the sophisticated harbor complex, confirming its status as a major Roman administrative center.

The famous 'Pilate Stone,' discovered in the Caesarea theater in 1961, is an inscription that confirms Pontius Pilate as the Prefect of Judea, validating the biblical account of Caesarea as his base (Acts 23:23-24).

While no artifact names Cornelius directly, inscriptions found elsewhere in the Empire (e.g., in Syria, dating to A.D. 69) mention the *Cohors Italica*, confirming the existence and deployment of such units in the eastern provinces during this period.
These findings provide a solid, historically verifiable context for the events described in Acts 10.
aggregate_perspective_and_analogia_scrip: Acts 10:1 sets the stage for a divine revolution, meticulously prepared by God throughout salvation history.
The 'certain man' is not incidental; he is the fulfillment of the promise to bless 'all nations' (Genesis 12:3).
His location, Caesarea, the seat of Gentile power, is precisely where God chooses to demonstrate that His kingdom supersedes all earthly empires.
His profession, a Roman centurion, the embodiment of that power, is the very person God calls to bow the knee to Christ.
This event is the practical application of Christ's own ministry to the Gentile centurion (Matthew 8:5-13) and the Syrophoenician woman (Mark 7:24-30).
Peter's subsequent realization, 'Truly I understand that God shows no partiality' (Acts 10:34), becomes the theological thesis statement for the rest of the New Testament's mission.
It validates the truth that in the Church, there is 'neither Jew nor Greek...for you are all one in Christ Jesus' (Galatians 3:28).

application_summary: God's work is not limited by our cultural, ethnic, or social boundaries. He actively seeks people from every background, even those we might consider outsiders or opponents.
We must be prepared for God to challenge our personal prejudices and comfortable traditions in order to advance His kingdom.
Notice the person in your life—at work, in your neighborhood—who seems farthest from your own experience. God may be preparing their heart just as He was preparing Cornelius's.
Our role is to be like Peter: willing to listen to the Holy Spirit and go where He sends us, even if it takes us into unfamiliar or uncomfortable territory.

Examine your own heart for any hidden 'walls of hostility' (Ephesians 2:14) you have built against a certain group of people. Pray for God to give you His heart for them, seeing them not as a category, but as individuals whom Christ died to save.
